column4: how do I recover my ubuntu feisty from a livecd if I messed up the file system and can't get to GRUB Menu?
Did you mess up the file system or just grub?

i think i messed up the file system, but I when GRUB is starting up, it gives me an error, its not even letting me choose the OS that I want.yesterday at 4am I did "fsck /dev/ext3" because it was taking too long in the ubuntu loading screen, and ever since I did that, i having been able to even get to the GRUB Menu.

Put in the live CD and see if you did mess up the file system.  If you did mess up the file system you will have to re-install Ubuntu (that will fix grub to).  But don't re-install if you don't have to.
i'm in the live cd now...lol...but i dont really know how to check if I messed up the filesystem
Type "mount" in a terminal to see if it is mounted.  If it is cd to the directory it is mounted to and see if you can read/write to the file sistem.
Or, you may be able to see it mounted on your desktop.  Been a while since I used the Live CD.

i just did this: ubuntu@ubuntu:~$ sudo blkid/dev/sda1: TYPE="ntfs" /dev/sda2: TYPE="swap" UUID="a9f15be7-49e5-498d-ba5a-d74e67439b00" /dev/sda3: UUID="55ae74a9-35a9-49fe-abc5-8515ac9d3222" SEC_TYPE="ext2" TYPE="ext3"
I dont really know what that means
Type "mount | grep /dev/sda3" and see where it is mounted.
it doesnt do anything when I typed "mount | grep /dev/sda3"
Ok, try this.  "cd /media", "sudo mkdir sda3", "sudo mount /dev/sda3 sda3"

this is what I'm getting after typing the last command: mount: wrong fs type, bad option, bad superblock on /dev/sda3,       missing codepage or other error       In some cases useful info is found in syslog - try       dmesg | tail  or so

this is what I'm getting after typing the last command: mount: wrong fs type, bad option, bad superblock on /dev/sda3,       missing codepage or other error       In some cases useful info is found in syslog - try       dmesg | tail  or so
did u see the message i got from doing that?
Yes, you didn't have to show it twice.  By the sounds of it you did mess up your file system if you can't mount the partition.  I would try a re-install of Ubuntu.
It's ok.  And that is my best opinion.  You may be able to get away without a re-install.
